text: Now begins the sections on pulses (dicotyledons—Shamidhanya—śamīdhānya-varga).

verse_id: The green gram is considered the best of pulses
text: It is astringent-sweet in taste, dry, cooling, pungent on digestion, light, limpid and curative of Kapha and Pitta.
The black gram is an excellent aphrodisiac, curative of Vata, unctuous, hot, sweet, heavy, strengthening; it increases fecal matter and quickly imparts virility.

verse_id: 25 The black eye pea is laxative, relish-giving, corrective of Kapha, semen and acid-dyspepsia
text: It is sweet in taste like black gram, Vata-stimulant, dry, astringent in action, limpid and heavy.
Horse-gram is hot, astringent in taste, acid on digestion and corrective of Kapha, semen and Vata, astringent in action and beneficial in cough, hiccup, dyspepsia and piles.
The moth-gram is sweet both in taste and on digestion, astringent in action, dry and cooling. It is recommended in hemothermia, in fevers and in similar conditions.
Chick-pea, lentils, vetchling and common pea are light, cooling, sweet, astringent in taste and strongly dehydrating.

They are recommended in Pitta and Kapha conditions and are esteemed as soups and ointmenes [ointments?]. Amongst them the lentil is astringent in action and chickling vetch is a great stimulant of Vata.
Til is unctuous, hot, sweet, bitter and astringent. It is a skintonic and hair tonic, strength-giving and curative of Vata and causative of Kapha and Pitta.
All varieties of legumes are sweet, cooling, heavy, destructive of strength and dehydrating. They should be taken only by strong persons and in conduction with unctuous articles.
The Shimbi [śimbi] variety of legume is dry, astringent in taste and provokes Vata in the abdomen and is nonaphrodisiac, not good for the eye and causes slow and irregular digestion.
Pigeon-pea is curative of Kapha and Pitta and stimulative of Vata. Babchi seeds and seeds of wild senna are curative of Kapha and Vata and Pitta.
